awd_titl_txt: Carbon-Detected NMR Studies of Intrinsically Disordered Protein Post-Translational Modification
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon-Detected NMR Studies of Intrinsically Disordered Protein Post-Translational Modification

Access to the genetic information encoded in DNA must be both rapid and under tight control so that a cell can readily adapt to its environment, or rapidly respond to growth signals.  One regulatory mechanism involves the use of proteins that have highly flexible regions that can be chemically modified in response to signals. These chemical modifications impact how these proteins associate with, or access, DNA and thus determine whether genetic information is accessible and expressed or hidden and suppressed. Thus, chemical modifications of these highly flexible proteins can exert timely control over cellular responses, acting to toggle their targets between active and inactive states and allowing the cell to quickly mobilize the resources it requires at the moment. Highly flexible regions are difficult to observe with current technologies; this fact significantly limits our understanding of how they function.  The investigator will push the boundaries of current technologies and explore the structural consequences of chemical toggles of highly flexible proteins that control the expression of genetic information.  This program addresses a significant gap in our knowledge of how gene expression is regulated. The research will train junior scientists at multiple education levels to seek fundamental insight into the biochemistry of biological processes using the principles and quantitative laws from the physical sciences. Among other outreach efforts, the investigator will bring middle school students from underprivileged backgrounds to Penn State to demonstrate the opportunities that arise from higher education in science and engineering fields. 

To achieve this project's objectives, new experimental methodology will be implemented for nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy of highly flexible proteins. While protons are relatively easy to observe by NMR, the PI has shown that the comparatively more challenging direct-detection of carbon yields more quantitative and complete information for intrinsically disordered polypeptides. Recently, the PI used this technique to demonstrate how serine phosphorylation of RNA polymerase II provides a structural switch that plays a role in regulating the critically important enzyme. The PI will now broaden the diversity of the highly flexible proteins that can be studied with carbon-detected NMR. Specifically, methods will be developed to overcome a current blind-spot for the aromatic amino acids tyrosine and phenylalanine. Second, the project will extend these studies to address the structural consequences of threonine phosphorylation. Finally, proteins that acquire phosphate in response to cellular and environmental signals often also acquire methyl groups. These modifications can exert combinatorial control, often in competition. Therefore, experiments will be performed to test the hypothesis that addition of methyl groups to the amino acid lysine also induces structural transitions, akin to those the PI has observed in association with phosphate incorporation. As a result, this research and associated training activities will yield fundamental, molecular level insights  into gene regulation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Access to the genetic information encoded in DNA must be both rapid and under tight control so that a cell can readily adapt to its environment, or rapidly respond to growth signals.  One regulatory mechanism involves the use of proteins that have highly flexible regions that can be chemically modified in response to signals. These chemical modifications impact how these proteins associate with, or access, DNA and thus determine whether genetic information is accessible and expressed or hidden and suppressed. Thus, chemical modifications of these highly flexible proteins can exert timely control over cellular responses, acting to toggle their targets between active and inactive states and allowing the cell to quickly mobilize the resources it requires at the moment. From a technological point of view, our objective was to develop new experimental approaches to evaluate the impact of chemical modifications on protein conformation, flexibility, and function. As a result, this program addresses a significant gap in our knowledge of how gene expression is regulated. This project provided ample training opportunities for junior scientists in biochemistry and molecular biophysics, while the outreach activities pursued yielded training opportunities and orientation to the educational experiences needed by youth who are interested in scientific careers.

Our laboratory has demonstrated a very exciting example of the influence phosphorylation of serine has on protein structure and function, which is often used to activate or inactivate molecular processes including gene expression. The protein RNA Polymerase II, which is responsible for creating the preliminary copies of genes needed to produce new proteins, is subject to extensive and reversible serine phosphorylation. We have described a novel regulatory mechanism whereby serine phosphorylation causes further structural changes in the protein when it is adjacent to the amino acid proline. Our first major activities in this project involved creating a broad panel of phosphorylation states for a regulatory region of RNA polymerase, demonstrating which protein sequences support this conformational change and which do not. The structural responses we documented contribute to the sequential organization of events that must occur while RNA polymerase II moves through its functional cycle. This process is also regulated by a protein named Spt5, which helps to pause RNA polymerase when it first accesses a gene, to allow an orderly beginning of the copying process, and then switches on RNA polymerase function in response to its own phosphorylation. In our second major activity, we have generated new tools to analyze the structural implications of these phosphorylation events, which will yield deep insight into the process of copying genetic information into the RNA templates that are used to bring about cellular functions.

Crosstalk between chemically distinct protein modifications is an important and under-explored area of protein biophysics. The third major accomplishment of this project was the development of new chemical methods to add methyl groups to the amino acid lysine in proteins and to detect and characterize the resulting modified amino acid spectroscopically. One of the most important examples of biological regulation through protein methylation is chemical modification of the histone proteins that serve a role similar to bobbins, threading the DNA that forms our genomes into compact structures that fit inside of our cells. We provided measurements of histone methylation events known to regulate the level of DNA compaction in a way that controls access to specific genes. This work contributed to a deeper understanding of how the enzymes that achieve these chemical changes are regulated.

Finally, we were able to make the major biochemical and biophysical observations described above because we have invested significant effort to develop new approaches in nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. In order to maximize the impact of our research, the computer code required for other investigators to implement our new experimental techniques is always distributed through the Penn State ScholarSphere. This initiative provides stable, open-access archiving of our results for use by any investigator. Community adoption of this technology was demonstrated through collaboration with researchers at the University of Michigan, who sent a graduate student to our laboratory to learn our protocols, apply them to a highly flexible protein at the center of his dissertation research, and bring standard operating procedures back to Michigan for optimal use of our publicly available experimental methods.

This project involved postdoctoral scientists, multiple graduate students, and undergraduate students. The environment in which this project was carried out benefited from our laboratory’s participation in the Penn State Center for Eukaryotic Gene Regulation, which provided a rich and interdisciplinary training environment for all project participants.
